intro: Pithecoctenium vitalba var. rostratum, commonly known as the narrow-leaved sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Southeast Asia. It typically grows in wetland or marshy environments, thriving in moist, nutrient-rich soils. The plant features narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets. It is characterized by its distinctive, elongated inflorescence and is often found in swampy or seasonally flooded areas. This variant is closely related to other species within the Cyperaceae family, sharing similar ecological and morphological traits.
